If you hit styro or deeper and the cut is quite wide, you can create your own steri strips out of regular bandaids. Be careful with these though because while steri strips are designed to fall off on their own after the right amount of time has passed, the self made ones don't. Don't remove them too soon or you'll reopen the yeets. If they don't need steristrips and you want to save your regular bandaids to make steristrips, you can use toilet paper or paper kerchiefs, be sure to use clean ones though, don't take ones from dirty public bathrooms or something or you'll end up with a nasty infection. You can keep the toilet paper in place with bandages (either you save for bandages or you try and take some from your first aid kit at home if you have one or from a school's doctor office) or with your clothes or bracelets/hair ties/elastic bands depending on where you yeet. Make sure to often replace the paper kerchiefs so that the dressing stays clean enough to not infect the cut. Keep in mind that if you use these you'll have to check often to see if you don't bleed through. Something you can't forget is to disinfect your wounds, if possible, use disinfectant, if not, at least use water and soap. Be sure to rinse the skin thoroughly so that no soap residue remains in the yeets.

What it feels like? Good at first, it gives you a relief you can't phantom yourself getting anywhere else but then the guilt sets in. And the self hate and shame follow quickly. All you can think is "what have I done?!" And you hope the scars disappear but they don't, they're a permanent mark but in the meantime you want that euphoria again because you feel so so horrible about having done it in the first place, you want to feel better once more. So you end up doing it again. And then you just spiral down the scars multiply and your sense of self loathing deepens, the first few months you were able to still wear regular clothing but then the scars have spread so much you start needing more clothes to cover up, you isolate yourself from loved ones, don't participate in things you used to enjoy until one day you get the help you need or you hurt the people that love you irreversibly. Yet that euphoria you felt wasn't a SH thing only. You can get it from exercising, drawing, laughing your head off, going for a run ... You can get the good feeling it gives you without the negative consequences by coping in a different way. Please stop before you even start because it's not worth it. I'm telling you this as someone who's doing it till this day, I'm not an ex-sh-er that can tell you about how recovery was worth it because I'm too ashamed to get the help I need. I'm telling you this as someone who recognises the problem but can't get away from it. None of this is worth it, it's a dark path and I really don't want any more people to fall victim to it so please, seek professional help. Tell them about the urges you're having. The fact that you're considering it is alarming enough, please seek help and stay safe, we love you #10084; #65039;

Yeeting has thought me some creative ways on how to change without the yeets being discovered.

Whenever I have gym class I make sure to wear something over sized or long to hide my thighs, then I just change my trousers first while using the sweater or shirt to hide the scars. If someone often looks at you, talk while you do it so they focus on your face, if they don't, try to get a spot in a corner of the room so you can stand with your back to the room so your front and sides are blocked from view. To hide the ones on my arms, I pull my arms out of my sleeves but keep them under the shirt, take my sports shirt, put my arms through those sleeves and pull that sports shirt over my head while simultaneously pulling my other shirt off so nothing gets exposed. If you have scars on your stomach and/or chest, just wear a top under your normal clothes and keep that one on while changing. Scars on ankles can easily be hidden by socks while scars on wrists can be hidden by bracelets or a bandana. If you can somehow not do it sneakily consider already wearing your sports clothes in advance so you just have to tug off a sweater or something. If possible, get in the changing room before others, or just change your clothes in a stall in the restrooms. Some changing rooms have one or two separate stalls (sometimes those are showers) just hop in there and change there. Most people wouldn't care to notice or comment on it.

I feel that on a spiritually level. A homeroom teacher is basically a teacher who gets a class assigned to them. They are then responsible for organising events, collecting and distributing documents (like fees, permission slips etc), they are supposed to help when there's a problem between a student and another teacher or student, help you find your way around the school, check in with your plans for university, give advice, ... Basically, they are responsible for a class and the students. They are also supposed to be the teacher that helps with problems that are not necessarily education based. I didn't tell my parents but I did tell someone else. I didn't handle it well at all, I just told here I needed to tell her something and when I got too nervous I just ran home and texted her a picture of my scars. I realise that that was not the right way to handle it at all. It wasn't fair to her to just send such a picture. But she was really supportive and told me that I could talk to her whenever the urge came but I of course never did that. I did however beg her to not tell anyone and till this day, she hasn't. But her demeanor towards me did change slightly. She's way more cautious with what she says around me now and I can no longer make suicidal jokes around her because she'd worry too much. I'd suggest to either talk about it in person, take a moment both you and your parents don't have plans, because it's a long and serious conversation. But, also make sure you can remove yourself from the situation if needed. Perhaps ask a friend if you can stay over if your parents get furious at you. If you're too scared to tell them face to face, consider leaving a note before leaving the house for the day. Write in the note what you do, why you do it and how it makes you feel. Explain why it's a coping mechanism for you and that you decided to finally get help but that them getting angry at you wouldn't help your situation at all and that you really need their support right now. And don't forget to mention that you're safe at the moment and are just going to hang out with a friend or something so they don't worry about your safety or what you could do right now. Leaving the note out gives you parents a whole day to digest the information and it can help you avoid initial anger. That way they can think about it and approach you way more level headed.

For all of you pancake lovers out there, here's a recipe for low kcal pancakes: Ingredients: 2 eggs 1 banana (if you are allergic to bananas or simply don't like the taste, you can use mashed apples instead) Cooking process: Peel the banana and place it on a plate/in a cup. Take a fork and proceed to mash the banana until it is mushy. Take the two eggs and add them to the mashed banana. Mix the two together. Take out a pan and put it on the stove, take your favourite low cal oil/butter/whatever you use and put a bit in the pan. Take the pancake mix and put two table spoons in the pan (the pancakes will be the small cute kind). Bake the pancakes and continue untill all the dough is gone. You can add some low kcal spreads or eat the pancakes plain. The banana gives them a unique taste. Enjoy.

EVERYONE with anorexia nervosa is underweight, what you're thinking of is atypical anorexia. (They're mostly the same thing except for the fact that people with anorexia nervosa are underweight and people with atypical anorexia don't meet the criteria of low weight.) But even if OP were to have atypical anorexia, people with anorexia don't consume enough vitamins, iron, etc. which makes their immune system severely lacking. People with anorexia (nervosa or atypical) are high risk groups for illnesses like Corona

Wtf, I never said that. I said everyone with anorexia nervosa is underweight however people that hit every criteria for anorexia nervosa except the underweight part don't have anorexia nervosa but atypical anorexia. Don't put words in my mouth, read my answer before assuming things. Both anorexia nervosa and atypical anorexia are serious illnesses that shouldn't be taken lightly. Everyone with an ED deserves treatment, I never said you didn't. I explained the difference between the two, I just explaining what the DSM-V says.

What you think is because of your anorexia (using the term as the umbrella term now) that says you're not worthy of treatment. However when people talk about anorexia, they're talking about the umbrella term. If you ask a random stranger "can people not underweight have anorexia?" They will most probably say yes. The difference between the two isn't all that known nor used in daily life, they're seen as the same illness. I'll try to explain it this way: Let's say I have OSFED, it's an ED rarely talked about but just as life threatening as any other, would that mean that I also don't deserve treatment? Purely based on the criteria of "being talked about", that would be the case. It would mean that even though I could be dying, I don't deserve treatment simply for the fact that you barely hear about it in your daily life. It's the same for atypical anorexia. Just because it isn't often talking about, doesn't mean it's not just as dangerous. When you have atypical anorexia the same dangers are there. Everything that happens in the body of someone with anorexia nervosa, happens in the body of someone with atypical anorexia. The same health risks are there, the same risks of heart diseases, turning infertile, kidney failure, fainting, skin changes, gastrointestinal issues, emotional difficulties, gastroparesis, heart palpitations and so much more. The only difference is the fact that their BMI isn't below the criteria. The criteria of "being talked about" does not indicate the danger of an illness. It actually makes said illness that much more dangerous. Because a patient isn't underweight, they think it's not as big of a deal. They're not underweight so why should they go seek help? But meanwhile they continue to struggle and their condition worsens. While people with anorexia nervosa get treatment because their ED has been spotted thanks to their weight, people with atypical anorexia have not. Their habits keep persisting until ultimately their heart just stops. While the person with anorexia nervosa got help and are slowly getting healthier, the person with atypical anorexia spiraled down until they eventually lost the battle. Mental health experts know the dangers of eating disorders, they are the mental illnesses with the highest mortality rate namely 20%. They would not turn someone away simply because they are not underweight. Every person that goes to a psychiatrist with concerns about having an ED gets taken seriously. Because all ED's are serious, wether it's anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, atypical anorexia, pica, OSFED, ARFID, ... They are all dangerous and every single sufferer deserves help, regardless of weight.

In my country people with mental health problems can request euthanasia. They conduct a psychological examination and when it's clear that the patient cannot be helped to find a happy life, that they'll suffer for the rest of their existence, then they will start the procedure. They have multiple psychological check ups (every week or every month, I don't remember the exact numbers) over around 2 years or more. Also therapy sessions with family members to help them come to terms with it. And then, ultimately, the day of the euthanasia, which is of course painless.

WRITING.TEXT: I have a nose piercing and let me tell you: I absolutely love it. I don't really have any positive or negative feelings towards my nose but I do despise my face in general. My piercing however made me hate it a little less. It makes me feel like the pretty jewelry is actually distracting people from my face and is making me look a little better. You also have a lot of options, there are so many cute designs, it's amazing. (Warning: I do sometimes feel insecure about my piercing, thinking that it would suit anyone but myself so if you get a piercing, you may have some of those days. Yet, if you absolutely love nose piercings, you won't regret it most days.)

Might I suggest buying a retainer as well? These are see through piercings that you can put in if for example your school/job doesn't allow piercings. If you put in a retainer the piercing appears "invisible" and it looks like you don't have one. If you have bad days where you hate your nose piercing, you can take it out, put in the retainer and the hole won't close. Then, if you're having a good day, you can once again wear the piercing because the retainer kept the hole open.

For a second I was confused by "the tooth kind" but then I REALISED and now I can't stop imagining a retainer through a nostril. And thank you :)) I have one because my previous school didn't allow piercings and then I thought "hey, this could be a great alternative for if you feel really low about your piercing without having to take it out, let the hole heal and never wear your piercing again"

Don't worry! It was skin-on fish, fish is actually recommended for cats. It contains a lot of Omega fatty acids and other healthy vitamines. We never cook our food in salt (cats can't really digest salt and raw fish is really bad for them) and I only gave the fish, no other human foods. Of course it shouldn't be given to cats on a daily basis but this was the first time he even had a real piece of fish (dry cat food with fish doesn't count and we never give them wet cat food since that's really unhealthy for them) so it's certainly not part of his daily diet. My cat isn't obese at all, he's at the right weight for a cat his size and age. (Before giving cats fish do look up the kind of fish you can feed cats cause some of them are really bad for the cuties)
Thank you so much! I enjoy a lot of daily cuddles with him, he's an angel. And he loved the fish, kept following and begging me for more! He's the absolute cutest

This is why I still trust bread (idk if it'll work for you but I hope it does): I only eat bread when it's homemade or from a warm baker (where I live warm bakers make everything themselves, cold bakers order frozen bread and sell that. Do not ask why cause idk) meaning the bread has no conservatives or added sugar (or no sugar except starch if you count that as sugar). Whole grain bread actually helps against diabetes, colon cancer, high blood pressure and obesity. (Read this in a study). The bread I buy has only around 72 kcal per 35 gram which is around the same as 2 rice cakes but you can find bread for even less kcal. I also find that bread is incredibly filling and can help me restrict longer than if I ate rice cakes instead. Bread also has a lot of nutrions which might help if restricting really hurts your body. And the biggest pro: toast, the food of the gods.
